content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are provided a markdown document `md` with julia language code blocks. Write a function `extract_julia_code` that extracts all the code blocks, removes code fences and joins the code blocks (if there are multiple) together with a newline. Return a String. Do not provide any examples.

You can use the `Markdown.parse` and `HTML` functions in the Documenter package for this task. Here's an example:

```julia
using Markdown

function extract_julia_code(md)
    blocks = split(md, "\n")
    code_blocks = []
    
    # loop through all lines in markdown
    for block in blocks 
        if startswith(block, "```julia")
            start_index = findnext('\n', block)
            if start_index != nothing
                end_index = findnext("```", block, start_index)
                if end_index != nothing
                    push!(code_blocks, block[start_index+1:end_index-2])
                end
            end
        end
    end
    
    # join all code blocks together with a newline
    return join(code_blocks, "\n")
end
```
This function loops over the lines in your markdown document. If it finds a line that starts with ```julia (which is a common way to start a code block), it then looks for the next occurrence of "```" after a newline and before the end of the block. 

If both conditions are satisfied, it extracts the relevant code between these markers, removes the fencing markers from each side, and appends this cleaned up code block to the list `code_blocks`. Once all the code blocks have been processed in this way, it joins them together into a single string separated by newline characters.

Remember to make sure your markdown document is correctly formatted with ```julia for starting each block and "```" at both ends of each block.
